abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Health Services
            Development Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The project
            achieved all of its major objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of the Bank
            was highly satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, it would be more appropriate, in situations
            such as Guinea's in 1980, to begin by addressing the
            sector in its entirety by means of adjustment or sector-wide
            investment operations with strong capacity-building
            components. Second, the question of whether cost recovery
            affects the accessibility of the poor to health services
            should be further addressed. Third, specific quality control
            measures and surveys should be carried out regularly to
            further improve utilization rates and health services
            outcomes. Fourth, weak family planning outcomes show that
            strong, high-level political support and a convincing effort
            to sensitize the target are needed from the start of the
            project. Proper primary health services are also needed to
            boost the demand for modern contraception. Finally,
            community-based activities should be developed, together
            with more general policy consensus processes, from the very
            beginning of the project.
